thread.title: Australia’s Major Banks Need More Capital to Rival Global Peers
thread.title_full: Australia’s Major Banks Need More Capital to Rival Global Peers - Bloomberg Business

author: Narayanan Somasundaram
title: Australia’s Major Banks Need More Capital to Rival Global Peers
text:
Australia’s largest banks will need to boost their capital ratios by at least 2 percentage points to be deemed among the safest lenders globally, a study by the country’s banking regulator shows.
While the nation’s biggest banks hold more capital than the 11.6 percent median of 98 lenders surveyed, they are below the 13.3 percent for the top quartile, the study by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority showed Monday.
The study will assist in setting capital levels, the watchdog said, while adding that it “does not intend to tightly tie” the requirements to a moving global benchmark.
Australia’s lenders are bracing themselves for higher capital requirements after a government review of the financial system recommended levels held by the top 25 percent globally. APRA also said it would soon respond to a recommendation by the review committee to set aside more capital for potential mortgage losses.
If mortgage risk weights were to rise, “it will have the effect of shifting these banks towards a stronger relative positioning against their global peers,” the regulator said.
The study is in response to the December recommendations by the government’s Financial Systems Inquiry, APRA said. It measured common equity Tier 1 ratios at the country’s major lenders -- Australia & New Zealand Banking Group Ltd., Commonwealth Bank of Australia, National Australia Bank Ltd. and Westpac Banking Corp. -- against global peers. Wells Fargo & Co., HSBC Holdings Plc, JPMorgan Chase & Co. and Royal Bank of Canada were among lenders included in the study.
‘Less Material’ Any changes to minimum capital requirements were “likely to be less material” for smaller banks, APRA said.
The top quartile positioning will be “a useful sense check of the strength” of the Australian lenders, the regulator said. “APRA is committed to ensuring any strengthening of capital requirements is done in an orderly manner.”
National Australia, which said it was well positioned to meet any additional capital requirements, fell 0.6 percent at 10:30 a.m. in Sydney, compared with a 0.5 percent drop for the benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index. Commonwealth Bank fell 0.7 percent, ANZ Bank declined 1.1 percent, while Westpac was down 0.5 percent.
